column1: The COVID-19 pandemic in Brazil is part of the ongoing pandemic of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2). The virus was confirmed to have spread to Brazil on 25 February 2020
column2: when a man from São Paulo tested positive for the virus. The disease had spread to every state in Brazil by 21 March. On 19 June 2020
column3: the country reported its 1 millionth case; at this time
column5: 000 reported deaths. As of September 2020
column6: Brazil has the third-highest number of confirmed COVID-19 cases in the world behind India and the United States. On 17 July 2020
column7: the country reported its 2 millionth case. On 8 August 2020
column8: the country reported its 3 millionth case with deaths exceeding up to 100
column9: 000. Brazil is one of the worst affected countries in the world.

column1: The pandemic has triggered a variety of responses from federal
column2: state and local governments
column3: having an impact on politics
column5: the environment
column6: and the economy. On 27 March Brazil announced a temporary ban on foreign air travelers and most state governors have imposed quarantines to prevent the spread of the virus.

column1: == Timeline ==
On 28 January 2020
column2: Brazil's Ministry of Health announced that a suspected case of COVID-19 was being investigated in Belo Horizonte
column3: involving a student that had recently returned from Wuhan
column5: the Ministry announced it was investigating two other suspected cases in Porto Alegre and Curitiba.On 3 February
column6: it was announced that the Brazilian government would assist in helping citizens in Wuhan return to the country; on 5 February
column7: two planes were sent to Wuhan to repatriate 34 citizens. The citizens and all other crew were to be quarantined and monitored for 18 days at a Brazilian Air Force base in Anápolis. They were released ahead of schedule on 23 February
column9: the first confirmed COVID-19 case in Brazil (and the first in South America as a whole) was announced by the Health Department of São Paulo — a 61-year-old man who had returned from Lombardy
column10: Italy. A second case was confirmed soon after in another person who had recently returned from Italy. On 28 February
column11: scientists of the University of São Paulo's Tropical Medicine Institute and the Adolfo Lutz Institute reported that they had sequenced the genomes of these two cases
column12: which had been separately introduced from Northern Italy to Brazil on two occasions. In an address on 6 March
column13: President Jair Bolsonaro advised residents to "strictly follow the experts' recommendations as the best protective measure"
column14: but that "there is no reason to panic".On 12 March
column15: it was reported that Bolsonaro's press secretary Fábio Wajngarten had tested positive for COVID-19
column16: prompting increased monitoring of Bolsonaro (who tested negative the next day) and his cabinet. Wajngarten had also interacted with U.S. President Donald Trump and Vice President Mike Pence during Bolsonaro's visit to Miami
column17: Florida on 7 March. The number of cases within the cabinet began to increase
column18: including Minister of Mines and Energy Bento Albuquerque
column19: and President of the Federal Senate Davi Alcolumbre; by 20 March
column20: Brazil had the second-largest number of cases among members of a federal cabinet
column21: overtaking Iran and behind only France.On 13 March
column22: the cruise ship Silver Shadow arrived from the Bahamas and docked in Recife
column25: including one suspected case of COVID-19. The ship was isolated by health authorities. On 17 March
column26: Brazil recorded its first death. At this time
column27: there were 291 confirmed cases in the country. By 20 March
column29: 000 confirmed cases across 23 of 26 states and also in the Federal District. By 21 March
column30: all Brazilian states had reported at least one confirmed case of COVID-19
column31: with the most recent being Roraima. In the month since Brazil's first confirmed case
column34: the Ministry of Health reported that Brazil had 3
column36: suggesting a mortality of 2.9%. Approximately 90% of deaths were people over 60 years of age
column37: and most were men. In 84% of deaths
column38: patients had at least one risk factor

column1: === April ===
6 April: President Jair Bolsonaro threatened to fire the Minister of Health
column2: Luiz Henrique Mandetta
column3: after they clashed. Following criticism

column1: 9 April: The federal government sent out its first financial assistance to the public. Over 2.5 million people received R$600 ($116).
10 April: Brazil confirmed the thousandth coronavirus-related death
column2: as the number of confirmed cases neared 20
column3: 000.The virus had reached remote locations; a Yanomami teen died of it in Roraima.14 April: The Ministry of Health reported a total of 25
column5: 532 confirmed deaths. Over 14
column6: 000 people were declared recovered
column7: although they were not confirmed virus-free
column8: only that they were discharged from a hospital or were asymptomatic.

column1: 16 April: President Bolsonaro fired the Minister of Health
column2: Luiz Henrique Mandetta
column3: over disagreements about social distancing guidelines. He said he would appoint a health minister who favored reopening businesses "as quickly as possible". Shortly afterwards
column4: Nelson Teich was appointed to replace him.

column1: 20 April: Several cities started to ease social isolation guidelines in favor of contact tracing. Some retail stores were allowed to open as long as customers wore masks
column2: the number of in-person customers was reduced
column3: and customer personal information was tracked.

column1: 24 April: Brazil confirmed more than fifty thousand cases.
30 April: Brazil overtook China in number of confirmed cases
column2: surpassing 87

column1: 3 May: Brazil confirmed more than a hundred thousand cases; the number of cases had doubled in less than 10 days.
7 May: Several cities in the northern states of Amazonas and Pará begun issuing lockdown measures in order to curb the spread of the virus. Other cities in other states consider doing the same.
9 May: Brazil confirmed more than ten thousand deaths; the number of deaths doubled in less than two weeks.
14 May: Brazil confirmed more than 200
column2: 000 cases; the number of cases had doubled in 11 days.The state of Ceará became the second most state in confirmed numbers
column3: overtaking Rio de Janeiro.15 May: Brazil's minister of Health
column5: resigns less than a month after being nominated. He cited similar reasons to his predecessor: his clashes with the president over the use of hydroxychloroquine
column6: the social distancing guidelines
column7: and being overruled on rules he was supposed to define. General Eduardo Pazuello assumed the role of Interim Minister of Health
column8: until an official replacement can be found.

column1: 26 May: Reuters reported that according to four officials
column2: the Ministry of Health's initial 13 March response to the pandemic was halted and scaled back by President Bolsonaro less than a day later
column3: with power transferred on 16 March from the ministry to the office of General Walter Souza Braga Netto

column1: 31 May: Brazil confirmed more than five hundred thousand cases; the number of cases had doubled in less than 14 days.
=== June ===
1 June: Brazil confirmed more than 30.000 deaths.
5 June: Brazilian government shuts down official website with COVID-19 daily reports
column2: and will no longer report total number of deaths and active cases.

column1: 6 June: Carlos Wizard
column2: new Secretary of Science and Technology of the Ministry of Health
column3: claims states are over-inflating the number of COVID-19 deaths in Brazil as a budget diversion scheme
column4: and calls to recount the total number of deaths.

column1: 7 June: The government decided that it will no longer publish cumulative COVID-19 numbers
column2: claiming that former numbers may have been misleading. The health ministry is to publish only the numbers of new cases and deaths in the past 24 hours. In response
column3: large media groups in the country established a council to keep recording and publishing data according to the original method
column4: amid claims that the government's initiative could be a maneuver to mislead the population instead.

column1: 9 June: A court order forces the Brazilian government to continue publishing cumulative case and death counts.
29 June: A study reports that two raw sewage samples collected independently on 27 November 2019 in Santa Catarina
column2: Brazil
column3: detected SARS-CoV-2 (100
column5: 66 days in advance of the first COVID-19 confirmed case in the Americas. Subsequent samplings were positive on 11 December and 20 February. These samples can show that SARS-CoV-2 has been circulating in Brazil since late November 2019.

column1: === July ===
6 July: President Bolsonaro has a fever and was tested for coronavirus.
7 July: President Bolsonaro tests positive for COVID-19.
25 July: President Bolsonaro tests negative for COVID-19.
30 July: First Lady Michelle Bolsonaro tests positive for COVID-19.
=== August ===
3 August: General Braga Netto
column2: the chief of staff to President Bolsonaro
column3: tests positive for COVID-19.

column1: 8 August: Brazil reaches three million infections and 100
column2: 000 deaths.

column1: 25 August: Senator Flávio Bolsonaro
column2: the eldest son of President Bolsonaro
column3: tests positive for COVID-19.

column1: === September ===
3 September: Brazil reaches four million infections and about 125
column2: 000 deaths.

column1: 9 September: A two month old child dies of COVID-19 in São Bernardo do Campo
column2: possible the youngest death in the ABC Region.

column1: === October ===
6 October: Brazil reaches five million infections.
== Responses ==
=== Scientific research and forecast ===
On 19 March
column2: scientists predicted up to 2 million deaths in Brazil in the worst-case scenario without measures to contain the virus. They pointed out that a policy of social distancing was one of the most effective measures given the lack of a vaccine.On 20 March
column3: experts from Italy warned that the coronavirus growth curve in Brazil would repeat that of European countries. An observatory with physicists from USP
column5: São Paulo State University
column6: University of Brasília
column8: UC Berkeley and the University of Oldenburg showed that the number of infected people
column11: and that the case total would exceed 3
column13: researchers began to mobilize to increase the availability of testing in Brazil. The Federal University of Rio de Janeiro was attempting to create a serology test
column14: as opposed to the more common PCR test
column15: to detect infections through a patient's blood samples.

column1: Minister of Health Luiz Henrique Mandetta said that the number of cases would increase exponentially until the end of June.On 23 March
column2: a report from FGV economist Emerson Marçal predicted a negative 2020 GDP of up to 4.4% due to the effect of the coronavirus.Eleven COVID-19 patients died after receiving high doses of the anti-malarial drug chloroquine in a study in Brazil. This was reported in mid-April. The study was halted.On 15 August 2020
column3: three joint-ventures began testing a new COVID-19 vaccine in Brazil. The origin of the research and development became a hugely debated issue
column4: further complicated by conspiracy theories spread by anti-vax groups and renowned political allies of Jair Bolsonaro
column5: Brazilian President along with xenophobia.

column1: === Preventive measures ===
On 13 March
column2: the Ministry of Health recommended that those travelling to Brazil self-isolate for at least 7 days on arrival.

column1: On 17 March
column2: Brazilian authorities partially closed their border with Venezuela. Health Minister Luiz Henrique Mandetta had urged closure of the border due to Venezuela's collapsing health system. The state of Santa Catarina declared a state of emergency
column3: and ordered the closure of all non-essential businesses
column5: inter-city and inter-state buses
column6: public meetings
column9: sporting events and religious services.On 18 March
column10: Rio de Janeiro and five other municipalities—São Gonçalo
column14: and Mesquita—in the state of Rio de Janeiro had declared a state of emergency to help contain the coronavirus.The following day
column15: the government of Rio Grande do Sul declared a public emergency situation. Among the measures adopted were the prohibition of interstate travel and the restriction of items purchased in the markets.On 20 March
column16: the government of Rio Grande do Norte declared a public emergency situation.On 21 March
column17: cases in São Paulo rose almost 40% in two hours. Deaths also increased in the period. The state issued a lockdown order for non-essential businesses
column18: lasting from 24 March⁠ through at least ⁠7 April.Cities in the Campinas region declared an emergency situation. In addition to the metropolis
column27: Sumaré and Águas de Lindoia issued decrees with special measures to contain the spread of COVID-19 cases. Valinhos and Vinhedo declared a state of public emergency.

column1: On 9 May
column2: the government of Rio Grande do Sul established a new social distancing plan. Given that some areas were more affected than others
column3: the local government organized the state in 20 sectors. Each sector is ranked – according to the number of cases
column5: and other factors – from Yellow (low risk)
column6: to Orange
column8: and Black (high risk). The goal of this scale is to be able to respond better to the current pandemic
column9: and allow the population on lower risk areas to return to a somewhat normal life.

column1: === Presidential responses ===
Despite the global impact of COVID-19 and repeated warnings from health experts and organisations
column2: President Bolsonaro has routinely downplayed its severity. He has described the threat of COVID-19 as being exaggerated
column3: and as being a "fantasy" created by the media. On 15 March
column4: Bolsonaro made an appearance during a pro-government rally in Brasília
column5: interacting with his supporters; the President faced criticism for his participation without taking precautions (such as wearing a mask)
column6: as it came on the heels of his press secretary being infected following his presidential visit to the United States. Later that day
column7: Bolsonaro claimed that businesses were profiting off "hysteria"
column8: and he said the public should not react with "neurosis."He has opposed proposals to suspend interstate travel between states with cases
column9: and the closure of businesses (including malls and weekly outdoor markets)
column10: arguing in the case of the latter that they were "extreme measures" that would hurt the economy. Governor of São Paulo João Doria criticised President Bolsonaro for his inaction on COVID-19
column11: which had required individual states to take on responsibilities that should have been taken on at the federal level. In mid-March
column12: panelaços began to occur in major cities such as Rio and São Paulo
column13: including protests in support of the president
column14: and others calling for his resignation. According to one poll
column15: 64% of Brazilians rejected the way Bolsonaro had been handling the pandemic

column1: According to some sources in Congress
column2: Bolsonaro was shutting down political dialogue on purpose. They claim he was forcing his impeachment as a way to mobilize his supporters.On 19 March
column3: President Bolsonaro's son Eduardo shared a Twitter post that which blamed the Communist Party of China for the worldwide spread of COVID-19. As China is Brazil's largest trading partner
column4: the post provoked criticism from Chinese diplomats such as Yang Wanming — who argued that Bolsonaro family was "the great poison of this country."On 21 March
column5: it was reported that Alcolumbre
column6: president of the Chamber of Deputies Rodrigo Maia
column7: and the leaders of the major parties in the National Congress
column8: no longer believed that they could conduct productive dialogue on COVID-19 with Bolsonaro. In a televised interview on 23 March
column9: Bolsonaro criticised the protests against him
column10: arguing that "the people will soon see that they were tricked by these governors and by the large part of the media when it comes to coronavirus". He described COVID-19 as being merely a "little flu".In a presidential address the next day
column12: criticising the use of "scorched earth" mitigation measures such as closing businesses and restricting travel
column13: questioning the closure of schools due to there being more infections among the elderly
column14: and accusing the media of spreading a "feeling of dread" among the population. He argued that the lives of Brazilians needed to return to normality
column15: and that "because of my background as an athlete
column16: I wouldn’t need to worry if I was infected by the virus. I wouldn’t feel anything or at the very worst it would be like a little flu or a bit of a cold."The address was met with a negative response by many Brazilian politicians
column17: as well as critics of Bolsonaro; in a Twitter post
column18: journalist Ricardo Noblat referred to it as the "first political suicide broadcast live on national radio and television." The ongoing public protests against the President intensified during and after the address.In a press briefing on 27 March
column19: Bolsonaro continued to downplay the possibility that COVID-19 could spread rapidly nationwide
column21: and that there was a possibility that portions of the population were already immune. In late-March
column23: Inc. and Twitter pulled social media posts by Bolsonaro that promoted hydroxychloroquine as an effective treatment for COVID-19
column24: with the companies considering them misinformation that could cause physical harm
column25: and a contradiction of authoritative health information respectively. Twitter also pulled a similar post by Bolsonaro that called for the reopening of the economy.On 28 April
column26: when a reporter pointed out that Brazil's death toll had surpassed China's
column29: but what do you want me to do?"On 7 July
column30: after announcing that he had tested positive
column31: Bolsonaro remarked "There’s no reason for fear. That's life"
column32: and continued to criticise lockdown measures
column33: arguing that "the majority of Brazilians contract this virus and don’t notice a thing"
column34: and that "You can't just talk about the consequences of the virus that you have to worry about. Life goes on. Brazil needs to produce. You need to get the economy in gear."

column1: == Impact ==
=== Economy ===
Economists expect an economic stagnation for the country in 2020. On 16 March
column2: the Ministry of Economy announced a stimulus package of R$147.3 billion (US$29 billion) to help the economy against the effects of the pandemic. The Brazilian government is also in negotiations with the New Development Bank to receive an aid package for its COVID-19 efforts; China received one billion USD from the same institution.On 21 March
column3: Economy Minister Paulo Guedes announced a series of aid measures to reduce the impact on the economy. A scholarship for self-employed professionals
column5: is being prepared
column6: in addition to the payment guarantee for workers who have reduced working hours.On 23 March
column7: government announced package of R$85.8 billion for states and municipalities. The amount includes transfers to the health area
column8: recomposition of transfers of constitutional funds and suspension of the maturity of debts of the states with the Union.The economy shrunk by an unparalleled 9.7 percent in the second quarter of 2020 and plunged Brazil into a recession.

column1: === Education ===
By 20 March
column2: the pandemic had impacted education all over the world. There were nationwide school closures in over 100 countries. However
column3: President Jair Bolsonaro announced few country-wide measures to slow the spread of the virus
column4: and because the federal government decided not to cancel classes in the whole country
column5: lower levels of government have done so on independently. Municipal
column6: state
column7: and private schools and universities had different reactions regarding the suspension of classes. Classes were suspended at once
column8: gradually or not at all. Some of them were replaced with distance education or simply postponed. Because of that
column9: there are only "localized" (as opposed to "national") school closures

column1: === Environment ===
The deforestation of the Amazon rainforest has accelerated during the COVID-19 pandemic in Brazil
column2: increasing by over half compared to baseline levels
column3: according to satellite imagery. COVID-19 threatens indigenous communities in the Amazon region.

column1: === Favelas ===
By 17 March
column2: residents of favelas in Rio de Janeiro suffered from a lack of water. Without water to clean themselves
column3: this made them vulnerable to the proliferation of coronavirus. Water did not reach parts of the Baixada Fluminense and the North Zone of Rio de Janeiro. Among the affected areas are the Chatuba de Mesquita
column5: Méier and Complexo do Alemão communities. The infectious disease doctor and pediatrician Cristiana Meirelles said that without clean running water
column6: the situation of fighting the epidemic would become catastrophic.Cufa (Central Única das Favelas
column7: a NGO that operates with Favelas) called for measures to contain coronavirus in favelas. Government actions did not include the economically fragile
column8: a contingent that totals more than 70 million people
column9: said the organization.Some areas of Maré had been without water for two days
column10: and other areas were reported to have been without water for two weeks.

column1: === Healthcare ===
Following the first reported cases in Brazil
column2: there were concerns whether its healthcare system would be able to deal with the pandemic. On 12 March
column3: the Ministry of Health requested an additional R$10 billion (US$2.1 billion) to the federal budget as part of its efforts to manage the pandemic. It estimated that 2
column4: 000 intensive care units would be immediately needed.On 18 March 2020 hospitals in São Paulo denounced a lack of health materials
column5: such as masks
column6: gloves and hand sanitizer
column7: caused by an increase in prices. According to them
column8: packages of masks went from R$4.50 in January to R$140 by 17 March. The government said it will negotiate with industry to meet the demand.In Salvador
column9: local shops experienced shortages of masks and hand sanitizer.

column1: Rio and five other municipalities in the state declared an emergency to contain the coronavirus. The municipalities of São Gonçalo and Guapimirim also declared a state of emergency; Niterói
column2: Nova Iguaçu and Mesquita declared an emergency situation in the area of public health.On 19 March 2020 scientists predicted up to 2 million deaths in Brazil in the worst-case scenario
column3: without measures to contain the coronavirus. They pointed out that maintaining social distance was one of the most effective measures in the absence of a vaccine. Their conclusion came after analyzing the growth curve of COVID-19 cases in Brazil. The contagion rate was the same as that registered in Italy
column4: as the number of infected people had been doubling every 54 hours. According to estimates
column5: the number of confirmed cases might reach 3
column6: 000 by 24 March. According to the Ministry of Health
column7: the number of infected patients would grow exponentially until the end of June. The mayor of Belo Horizonte
column11: for the temporary assignment of 51 professionals from the army garrison to assist in the demands of fighting the coronavirus. The Brazilian Army has not yet said whether it will meet this demand. Peak cases of COVID-19 in Belo Horizonte were expected to occur in the first week of April. In an interview
column12: the health secretary announced the creation of two more Respiratory Disease centers and was studying placing PMs to serve the population.The Government of Rio Grande do Sul decreed a public emergency situation
column13: with measures including the prohibition of interstate travel and the restriction of items purchased in the markets
column14: with the decree in force from 19 March 2020.

column1: Employees at four public hospitals in the city of São Paulo reported a shortage of materials such as alcohol gel
column2: masks and gloves when caring for patients with suspected coronavirus. Professionals in the Sistema Único de Saúde (SUS) reported a shortage of masks and rationing of gel alcohol
column3: though the situation of public-service workers was different from that of private hospitals in São Paulo.

column1: Stores specializing in medical supplies no longer had alcohol gels and masks
column2: including N95 masks used by health professionals. Street vendors were reported to be taking advantage of the demand for equipment and trying to profit from it.

column1: On 20 March the press reported that Brazil was contradicting the recommendation of the World Health Organization by only testing patients in a severe condition. João Gabbardo
column2: executive secretary at the Ministry of Health
column3: said that the criteria adopted would not change
column4: and people with serious cases would be tested for COVID-19. The following day
column5: a group of scientists announced they were developing new COVID-19 tests in Brazil. They expect to elaborate a test which will work with a single drop of blood from the patient. They expected it to be ready during the current outbreak of COVID-19
column6: and hoped to engage some of the main Brazilian universities in its development.

column1: Without protective items
column2: health workers improvised caps as masks in hospitals. In addition to the first cases of coronavirus in Acre
column3: health professionals in the state had to deal with the lack of personal protective equipment (PPE). Some agents improvised with caps as masks.On 31 March
column4: the U.S. federal government donated two million doses hydroxychloroquine to Brazil
column5: for prophylactic and therapeutic use.Health professionals in the state of Rio de Janeiro (RJ) complained about the lack of conditions to work with patients in COVID-19. Doctors said there were no N95 masks
column6: with a more efficient filter
column7: at Hospital Salgado Filho. Unions said there was a shortage of personal protective equipment in hospitals.

column1: === Religious services ===
Dom Odilo Scherer
column2: Archbishop of São Paulo
column3: had initially defended the position that churches should not be closed
column4: arguing that there should be more daily services to diffuse large gatherings. Later
column5: he declared the suspension of celebrations with the people. Bishop Edir Macedo
column6: founder of the Universal Church of the Kingdom of God
column7: also declared that services should not be suspended
column9: leader of Assembleia de Deus Vitória em Cristo. Malafaia said he would only close his churches if mandated by a court order. Macedo caused greater controversy after he dismissed coronavirus as a creation of the media.

column1: === Television programming ===
Brazilian networks started airing prevention tips during their programming. Globo
column2: SBT
column3: RecordTV
column5: and RedeTV! announced they would stop production of all of their telenovelas
column6: and would record their talk shows without a live audience
column7: while expanding journalism in their programming.
